keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including traditional signals like gunfire or animal behavior, plays a vital role in early warning systems in Pakistan’s mountainous regions.
Residents in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa rely on human-based early warning systems due to distrust in technologically installed systems that often fail or are not maintained.

Despite spending millions on early warning infrastructure, such as the $37 million GLOF-II project, there is widespread community skepticism due to malfunctions, lack of follow-up, and poor communication.
A critical gap exists between government technology investments and local community trust and participation in disaster preparedness.
The effectiveness of Indigenous knowledge in saving lives—such as Wasiyat Khan’s timely alert—demonstrates a more resilient and culturally grounded approach to climate adaptation.
Pakistan, despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions, is among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable countries due to rapid warming (1.3°C since 1950) and glacier melt.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from the Roshan valley of Ghizer, Gilgit-Baltistan, who alerted villagers to a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOF) and saved lives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wasiyat Khan exemplifies how Indigenous knowledge and personal initiative are critical in real-time disaster response in the absence of functional official systems.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mohammad Hussain illustrates how intergenerational Indigenous knowledge—such as sound patterns and natural signs—is still actively used in daily community risk assessment.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Pakistan's mountainous regions, particularly in Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge—such as using gunfire, animal behavior, or natural signs to predict glacial floods—is proving more effective than government-installed early warning systems. Despite a $37 million investment in technology like the GLOF-II project, communities have expressed deep distrust due to frequent failures, lack of maintenance, and poor communication. Real-life examples, like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, show how traditional, human-based warning systems have successfully saved lives during glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). These cases underscore the need for community trust, local participation, and integration of traditional knowledge into climate adaptation strategies, especially given Pakistan’s status as one of the world’s most climate-vulnerable nations despite minimal carbon emissions.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
